p: Control and elimination of many zoonoses requires regional coordination to avoid re-introduction and to plan effective strategies for sustainable elimination. For example, bioregional approaches are proposed between Mexico and the USA (Pezzoli et al. 2014) and between the countries of the former Soviet Union (Bartholomew et al. 2015). Regional initiatives like the European Early Warning and Response System (EWRS, https://ewrs.ecdc.europa.eu/accessed 31 December 2017) would have the potential to be cross linked with animal disease surveillance. Global initiatives like the Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network (GOARN) http://www.who.int/ihr/alert_and_response/outbreak-network/en/ currently concentrate only on public health institutions, but the joint FAO-OIE-WHO Global early warning system for health threats and emerging risks at the human–animal–ecosystems interface (GLEWS www.glews.net) is a truly integrated global iSRS.
